I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

Comments_List: This class was an overview introduction into all aspects of maple sugaring.
I honestly learned everything I could have possibly hoped to know about maple syrup, from tree to table!  Seriously, all of it.
How to organize a sugarbush and maple operation!

I feel as though I have developed a practical understanding of maple syrup production practices, marketing strategies, and a general grasp of how the industry operates as a whole. As someone with no real experience in Maple, I am walking away having learned a lot. I think I learned the most from Joe's own experiences and what he was able to teach us from first hand expertise.
Biology of maple and related tree species, as well as the operations of a sugarbush and maple operation.

Tons. How sap is collected (tubing, etc.) as well as sap processing. Cultural aspects of sugar making. Value added products, why it comes out the way it does. Off tasting sap and why, different types of syrup beyond maple (birch, etc.). Greater appreciation for maple syrup in general after knowing just what goes into it.

Understanding the practice of sugar making from historic practice to equipment utilized and causes of off tastes. This class inspired me to take on the "hobby" of sugar making and I definitely gained an appreciation for the work and TIME involved.
Understanding the maple syrup industry and some of the science behind it.
A lot of knowledge about the whole maple sugaring operation -- Joe really knows his stuff!
Learned about the maple-making process and some forest management techniques related to managing a maple sugarbush.
The forest management and production process for maple syrup.
It aligned with my expectations. I was impressed with the breadth of maple-related topics that we covered.
Blew em away!
Met and exceeded my expectations.
I learned even more than I perhaps envisioned I would. I think I am coming away with a fairly nuanced understanding of a lot of the mechanisms behind syrupping.
Very well--course stuck to syllabus and what was taught built on previous lessons.
As expected (or exceeded)
It was exactly what I thought it was going to be.
Very well.
Well.
This course fully aligned with my expectations.
we learned all the ins and outs of the maple syrup industry.

The main weakness of this class was the structure of the project. I was in a group of 10 people for the project, which is just too big and doesn't facilitate a group atmosphere in which everyone contributes to the work or works efficiently.

This course's strength was eating maple syrup in class! Kidding, kind of. That's true, but also I really appreciated Joe's clear, infectious love for the subject. He made it really fun to learn.
If I could take this class over again, exactly how it was this semester, I would do it.  Any change at all would make it worse.  It was awesome!
Strengths are the broad range of topics covered in relation to sugar mapling. Weakness was the project for me.

I really enjoyed the course overall. I think for the amount of time we had Joe did a really good job covering as much material as he could but also having a relaxed lecture environment such that people felt comfortable asking clarifying questions and fleshing out certain concepts if need be. I think this was the right way to approach it given that we did not have a ton of time every week to discuss and had to make it through a certain amount of content. I also really enjoyed getting to go outside whether it be on the fields trips or even just out behind Marsh to help us novices get a sense of what syrupping actually looks and feels like.
Very strong course.

Strengths: Material is great. Professor Orefice is a very engaging lecturer. Field trips were fantastic and I liked that we were encouraged to try boiling sap and making maple syrup ourselves.

Weaknesses: Can't think of any
I feel that we could had went on more field trips for the class visiting different scales of producers and viewing the different techniques and equipment utilized.
The field components were fun, and important for understanding how trees are tapped.

This class was both interesting intellectually and very hands-on, which was awesome -- we took several field trips in order to experience the maple sugaring process first-hand, which really added a lot to the course.

The lectures were sometimes a little disorganized and Joe tended to go off on some tangents, so a little more structure and organization to the syllabus would have been good.

This course made it possible for students to learn the basics about how maple products are made and marketed. We also had a few field trips and a class project. However, I do wish that there had been more opportunities for us to engage with the material outside of class (with the understanding that it was a one-credit course).
instructor is incredibly knowledgeable of the subject, class was informative and hands on. Could have been interesting to visit more producers.
Take this class if you're interested in maple!

Ask yourself one question: do you want to learn about all things relating to maple syrup?  This class is going to teach you about maple trees, forests, sap collection systems, boiling sap, marketing, history, all of it.  If all you want to know is some super specific thing like "hey can I use maple syrup in this salad dressing?" then maybe just talk to Joe for 20 minutes one day, you'll probably be bored with most of the course material.  But if you wanna learn about maple syrup, tree to table, then do yourself a favor and TAKE THIS CLASS!
Great class that gives you practical understanding of a unique way of managing a forest.
I do not have a whole lot of advice, just make sure to take advantage of all the opportunities inside and outside the classroom to ensure you get the most out of the course.

Take it. You will not regret it. You learn a lot, will experience Professor Orefice's hilarious anecdotes and personal experiences related to maple, listen to a guest speaker, take field trips, etc.

Did I mention the maple syrup tastings??

If you were ever considering or wanted to understand the process in sugar making, then I highly encourage you to take this course. There is more to sugar making than just boiling down a lot of sap to produce a little bit of syrup.
Definitely take it -- I found it both fun and interesting to fully explore the maple syrup life-cycle, from tree to table (as the name implies).

If you are interested in forest management for non-timber products, rural development, or food systems/agroforestry, this is a great course to provide one case study example for many of those issues! If you don't think you can think about maple syrup for an entire semester, this might not be the right course for you.
